study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the benefits and harms of aerobic exercise on pain, function, quality of life, psychological functioning, and adverse events compared to placebo, sham treatment, attention control, or no treatment.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, as it describes a protocol for a Cochrane Review rather than reporting findings.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: To evaluate whether combining aerobic exercise with resistance training improves metabolic markers in postmenopausal women with type 2 diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvement in HbA1c levels but noted a significant improvement in HOMA-IR index, though the quality of evidence was very low.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus.
effective_dosage: Exercise intervention ranged between two to four days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically investigate the effects of aerobic exercise on quality of life, cognitive performance, and depressive symptoms in people with Alzheimer's disease (AD).
results_summary: Aerobic exercise improved cognitive function (MMSE and ADAS-cog scores) and quality of life but did not significantly affect depressive symptoms. Subgroup analysis indicated optimal benefits with durations greater than 16 weeks and specific session lengths (30-50 minutes).
population_specificity: Individuals with Alzheimer's disease (AD).
effective_dosage: More than three interventions per week, 30-50 minutes per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to update evidence on the antidepressant effects of aerobic exercise in youth, investigate dose‒response relationships, and provide insights for future research and clinical treatment.
results_summary: Aerobic exercise significantly reduced depressive symptoms in youth, with notable dose‒response relationships observed across age groups, intensity, and duration of intervention. A moderate-intensity program (25-40 min, 3 times/week for 9-15 weeks) was most effective.
population_specificity: Youth (combined sample size of 1308 participants)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether aerobic exercise promotes cognitive recovery in a mouse model of vascular cognitive impairment and dementia (VCID) through the ANXA1/MAPK axis.
results_summary: Aerobic exercise improved spatial memory, white matter integrity, and hippocampal function in BCAS mice by enhancing synaptic protein expression, reducing inflammation via ANXA1 upregulation, and suppressing MAPK signaling. These effects were linked to astrocyte polarization toward the A2 phenotype.
population_specificity: BCAS (bilateral common carotid artery stenosis) mice, a model for vascular cognitive impairment and dementia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the dose of aerobic exercise needed, based on the FITT-VP model, to achieve clinically relevant pain reduction in fibromyalgia patients.
results_summary: Aerobic exercise showed significant pain reduction (MD -0.49; CI [-0.90, -0.08; p = 0.02]) with moderate to low heterogeneity, advocating tailored dosing for optimal adherence and outcomes.
population_specificity: Fibromyalgia patients
effective_dosage: 2-3 times weekly, 25-40 minutes per session, aiming for >100 minutes weekly, starting at low intensity and gradually increasing over 6-12 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of treadmill exercise combined with metformin in improving cognitive impairment and its molecular mechanisms in T2DM rats.
results_summary: Aerobic exercise combined with metformin improved cognitive decline, reduced neuroinflammation, and promoted hippocampal neurogenesis in T2DM rats by upregulating the Wnt/β-catenin pathway.
population_specificity: T2DM rats induced by high-fat diet and low-dose streptozotocin.
effective_dosage: Treadmill exercise (specific dosage not detailed) and metformin (70 mg/kg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of a sub-symptom threshold aerobic exercise intervention on symptom burden and quality of life in adults with persistent post-concussive symptoms (PPCS) after mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI).
results_summary: The 12-week aerobic exercise intervention significantly improved overall symptom burden, quality of life, dizziness, and exercise tolerance, with additional improvements in headache and depressive symptoms in the immediate intervention group. No changes were observed in autonomic function measures.
population_specificity: Adults (mean age 42.6 years, 74% female) with PPCS and exercise intolerance, averaging 25.1 months post-mTBI.
effective_dosage: Sub-symptom threshold aerobic exercise (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the mechanisms by which aerobic exercise improves insulin sensitivity in MAFLD, particularly focusing on exosomal pathways involving miR-324 and its target ROCK1.
results_summary: Aerobic exercise significantly reduced liver fat and improved insulin sensitivity in MAFLD patients and HFD mice. Exercise-induced exosomal miR-324 from adipose tissue targeted ROCK1, revealing a novel mechanism for exercise's hepatoprotective effects against insulin resistance.
population_specificity: 15 MAFLD patients and high-fat diet (HFD) mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how different intensities of aerobic exercise reprogram the immune microenvironment of epididymal adipose tissue in nutritionally obese mice.
results_summary: Aerobic exercise improved morphology and blood indexes, reduced liver lipid content, decreased adipose tissue inflammation, and downregulated inflammatory markers. High-intensity intermittent exercise (HF-T) showed the most significant effects.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J male obese mice induced by a high-fat diet.
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercise intensity groups: moderate-intensity continuous, high-intensity continuous, high-intensity intermittent).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of physical exercise on pathological features of Alzheimer's disease, including tau tangles, amyloid plaques, iron deposits, and ferroptosis in the hippocampal formation of aged rats.
results_summary: Physical exercise reduced inflammaging, improved axon-myelin volume relations, and showed statistical correlations with reduced tau, amyloid, and iron levels in hippocampal formation cells. The study suggests beneficial effects of exercise on Alzheimer's disease pathology.
population_specificity: Aged rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the dose-response association of aerobic exercise with adiposity measures in adults with overweight or obesity.
results_summary: Each 30 minutes per week of aerobic exercise was associated with modest reductions in body weight, waist circumference, and body fat percentage. Aerobic exercise exceeding 150 minutes per week at moderate intensity or greater led to clinically important reductions in waist circumference and body fat.
population_specificity: Adults with overweight or obesity (mean age 46 years, 61% female).
effective_dosage: 30 minutes per week to 300 minutes per week of aerobic exercise.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the acute effects of aerobic exercise on mood and brain function in emerging adults, a population susceptible to mental disorders.
results_summary: The study found that aerobic exercise was associated with changes in mood and brain function, as measured by mood scales and resting-state fMRI scans, though specific outcomes were not detailed in the abstract. The dataset provides a resource for further analysis of these effects.
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers aged 17 to 24.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic exercise on a cycle ergometer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of high-intensity inspiratory muscle training (H-IMT) combined with aerobic and resistance training in reducing arterial stiffness (measured by baPWV) in individuals with stable COPD.
results_summary: The study is designed as a three-arm RCT to assess the impact of H-IMT alone and in combination with exercise on arterial stiffness, with primary outcomes measured at eight weeks and secondary outcomes tracked up to 32 weeks. Results are pending as the study is ongoing.
population_specificity: Individuals with stable COPD in a community setting.

study_goal: To investigate the effect of aerobic exercise (AE) on bone mineral density, muscular strength, exercise capacity, and health-related quality of life in patients with osteoporotic systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
results_summary: Aerobic exercise combined with progressive resisted exercise (PRE) showed statistically significant improvements in knee muscle strength, exercise capacity, and health-related quality of life compared to either exercise alone or traditional medical treatment. BMD increased significantly in the combined and PRE groups but not in the AE-only group.
population_specificity: 80 SLE patients aged 30-50 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of combining transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) with low-intensity aerobic exercise on chronic fatigue in patients with granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA).
results_summary: The study found that tDCS combined with aerobic exercise significantly reduced chronic fatigue by approximately 60% in the active tDCS patient, nearly double the improvement seen in the sham patient. The active tDCS patient also showed improvements in physical activity, functional capacity, handgrip strength, daily activities, and sleep quality, while the sham patient exhibited declines in physical activity and minimal fatigue improvement.
population_specificity: Two patients with granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA).
effective_dosage: Low-intensity aerobic exercise (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 12-week program of caloric restriction and aerobic exercise could improve PMS symptoms, anthropometric measures, and hormonal parameters in obese females with PMS.
results_summary: The study found that the combination of caloric restriction and aerobic exercise significantly improved PMS symptoms, reduced weight, BMI, waist and hip circumferences, W/H ratio, and serum cortisol levels, while increasing serum progesterone levels compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Obese females with premenstrual syndrome (PMS).
effective_dosage: Not specified (aerobic exercise program details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the acute effects of cocoa flavanols (CF) combined with aerobic exercise on glucose uptake and inflammatory mediators in insulin-resistant rats.
results_summary: CF combined with aerobic exercise improved glucose uptake, enhanced Akt and AMPK phosphorylation, reduced TRB3 gene expression, elevated CPT-1a gene expression, and ameliorated inflammation in insulin-resistant rats.
population_specificity: Insulin-resistant Wistar rats (15 weeks old, 250 ± 10g).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between obesity, dietary content, weight loss, and cortisol concentrations in postmenopausal women with overweight and obesity, specifically examining the effects of aerobic exercise combined with weight loss.
results_summary: The study found significant weight loss (-8%) but no significant changes in basal cortisol or cortisol suppression after dexamethasone suppression test (DST) following the intervention. Basal glucose levels and glucose AUC were associated with basal cortisol levels at baseline.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women with overweight and obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how different types of acute aerobic exercise (moderate intensity, high cognitive-demand, and high physical-demand) affect inhibitory control compared to a rest condition.
results_summary: All interventions reduced reaction times in the Flanker task, with high physical-demand exercise showing greater reductions for both congruent and incongruent trials, and high cognitive-demand exercise improving reaction times specifically in incongruent trials. The study concluded that higher cognitive and physical engagement during exercise enhances inhibitory control more effectively.
population_specificity: 25 young adults (mean age 20.20 years, SD=0.91).
effective_dosage: 20-minute sessions of each exercise type (moderate intensity, high cognitive-demand, high physical-demand) and rest condition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether aerobic exercise attenuates insulin resistance by restoring branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs) homeostasis and enhancing AMPK activity in diet-induced obese mice.
results_summary: Aerobic exercise improved insulin sensitivity, increased BCAAs catabolic protein expression, and reduced plasma BCAAs levels in obese mice. BCAAs supplementation counteracted these benefits by impairing insulin signaling and AMPK activity.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6J mice with diet-induced obesity.

study_goal: To examine the effects of long-term aerobic exercise on oxidative stress and learning memory ability in APP/PS1 mice, focusing on the hippocampal Keap1/Nrf2/GPX4 pathway.
results_summary: Aerobic exercise significantly improved cognitive function, reduced oxidative stress markers (MDA, ROS), increased antioxidant activity (SOD), and modulated protein expression (Keap1, Nrf2, HO-1, GPX4) in the hippocampus of AD mice.
population_specificity: APP/PS1 double transgenic Alzheimer’s disease (AD) mice and non-transgenic controls.
effective_dosage: Swimming training (specific duration/frequency not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the protective effect of aerobic exercise training (AET) on myocardial ischemia-reperfusion injury (MIRI) and its underlying mechanism involving m6A RNA methylation and the Nrf2/HO-1 signaling pathway.
results_summary: AET significantly improved cardiac function, reduced myocardial injury and fibrosis, and protected against MIRI by lowering m6A RNA methylation levels and modulating METTL3 expression. In vitro experiments confirmed that reduced m6A methylation and METTL3 expression increased resistance to hypoxia/reoxygenation-induced injury, with AET regulating the Nrf2/HO-1 pathway to attenuate MIRI.
population_specificity: Mouse model of MIRI and primary cardiomyocytes in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of HRV-Biofeedback training on recovery parameters after aerobic exercise in soccer players.
results_summary: The study found that HRV-Biofeedback training significantly shortened HRV recovery parameters after exercise, indicating faster cardiovascular recovery in athletes who underwent the training compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Twenty-four soccer players aged 18-24.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the antihypertensive effects of aerobic exercise, dynamic resistance exercise, isometric resistance exercise, and combined exercise in hypertensive patients.
results_summary: The study found that all types of exercise significantly reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure in hypertensive patients, with no significant differences in effectiveness between aerobic and resistance exercises.
population_specificity: Hypertensive patients aged 18 years or older.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of aerobic exercise (AE) in reducing cardiovascular risk factors in female breast cancer patients and assess the quality of the synthesized evidence.
results_summary: The study found that AE reduced the incidence of cardiovascular disease events by 29.4% and coronary artery disease events by 36%, while also improving LVEF, reducing weight, and hip circumference. Subgroup analysis showed nonlinear AE increased VO2max and reduced fat mass, while linear AE reduced LDL-C.
population_specificity: Female breast cancer patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of aerobic exercise on sleep disorders in menopausal women and propose an optimal exercise program based on frequency, duration, form, and mode.
results_summary: Low- and moderate-intensity aerobic exercise showed a moderate effect size in improving sleep disorders in menopausal women, with optimal results achieved at 3 times/week, 70-90 min/session, lasting 8-10 weeks, using static exercise forms and individual practice modes. Group exercise improved persistence but had a lesser effect size.
population_specificity: Menopausal women with sleep disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether aerobic exercise is beneficial in treating depression in adults.
results_summary: The review found substantial evidence supporting aerobic exercise's potential to alleviate depressive symptoms, with positive effects noted in multiple reviews and meta-analyses. Aerobic exercise also improved cardiorespiratory fitness (CRF) and showed neurobiological benefits in people with major depressive disorder (MDD).
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-65 with depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of aerobic exercise compared to other interventions in reducing pain intensity and disability in individuals with neck pain.
results_summary: Aerobic exercise alone was not statistically different from no-treatment or other interventions for pain intensity, but it showed positive results when combined with other therapies like strengthening exercises or acupuncture. The evidence was limited, low-quality, and heterogeneous.
population_specificity: Adults over 18 years old with neck pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if combining ischemic preconditioning (IPC) with aerobic exercise enhances post-exercise hypotension (PEH) compared to aerobic exercise alone.
results_summary: The study found that IPC combined with aerobic exercise significantly reduced systolic blood pressure during sleep compared to exercise alone, with sustained baroreflex sensitivity (BRS) up to 24 hours post-exercise. No differences were observed in BP or heart rate responses during exercise and 1-hour recovery between conditions.
population_specificity: Twelve pre- or hypertensive men (six prehypertension, six stage 1 hypertension).
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of aerobic exercise at 50% VO2peak.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the cardio-protective effects of moderate-intensity aerobic exercise and its mechanism in reducing myocardial ischemia-reperfusion injury by modulating NLRP3.
results_summary: Moderate-intensity aerobic exercise improved cardiac function, reduced myocardial injury and inflammatory response, decreased infarction area and cell apoptosis, and lowered NLRP3 expression and related inflammatory factors in mice.
population_specificity: C57BL/6N mice with induced myocardial ischemia-reperfusion injury.
effective_dosage: Moderate-intensity aerobic exercise (50-70% VO2max) on a treadmill.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of aerobic exercise on total hippocampal formation volume and subfield volumes in people with schizophrenia, as well as its potential clinical implications.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no significant effect of aerobic exercise on total hippocampal formation volume, but original data suggested significant volume increases in specific subfields (cornu ammonis and dentate gyrus). The study highlights the need to focus on subfields and identify patient subgroups responsive to exercise.
population_specificity: People with schizophrenia (186 in meta-analysis, 29 in original data; 100 male, 86 female in meta-analysis; 20 male, 9 female in original data).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Agmatine as an NMDA receptor antagonist in treating various neurological disorders.
results_summary: Agmatine showed encouraging results in animal models of brain diseases such as stroke, epilepsy, and Alzheimer's disease, suggesting therapeutic potential. The study highlights its role as an NMDA receptor antagonist but does not provide detailed efficacy data.
population_specificity: Animal models (mice) with neurological disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the anti-inflammatory effects of agmatine as a potential therapeutic approach for major depressive disorder (MDD).
results_summary: The abstract suggests that agmatine, along with other nutraceuticals, possesses anti-inflammatory effects that may contribute to its antidepressant properties, though further studies are needed to confirm its therapeutic benefits for MDD.
population_specificity: Individuals with major depressive disorder (MDD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Irvingia gabonensis (African Mango) on metabolic syndrome, insulin sensitivity, and insulin secretion.
results_summary: African Mango significantly reduced waist circumference, glucose levels, triglycerides, VLDL, and glucose AUC, with 58.3% of treated patients showing remission of metabolic syndrome compared to 16.7% in the placebo group.
population_specificity: 24 patients with metabolic syndrome as per International Diabetes Federation criteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the metabolic effects of arginine (Agmatine precursor) and fluoride toothpastes on supragingival plaque in adults with varying caries status.
results_summary: The study found that 14% of caries lesions became inactive after 12 weeks, with enamel lesions more likely to improve than dentin lesions. Arginine toothpaste influenced plaque metabolism via the arginine deiminase pathway, suggesting potential anticaries effects.
population_specificity: 83 adults with different caries status (caries-free and carious tooth surfaces).

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the physiological significance of agmatine as an endogenous ligand for α.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings regarding agmatine's effects, only noting its rediscovery as an endogenous ligand.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether agmatine could reduce ASD-like symptoms in a VPA-induced autism model in mice.
results_summary: Agmatine was among the agents that successfully reduced ASD-like symptoms in the VPA-induced model, though complete prevention of symptoms was rare. The abstract suggests agmatine affects brain neurotransmitters to achieve these effects.
population_specificity: Mouse offspring exposed to VPA on postnatal day four.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective effects of agmatine in various CNS cell lines and animal models against multiple forms of neurotoxicity and injury.
results_summary: Agmatine demonstrated significant neuroprotective effects against excitotoxicity, oxidative damage, corticosteroid-induced neurotoxicity, ischemic/hypoxic injury, spinal cord injury, traumatic brain injury, and retinal ganglion cell toxicity. The neuroprotection is attributed to its multimolecular biological effects, including glutamatergic receptor antagonism.
population_specificity: CNS cell lines and animal models (specific species not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore agmatine's role in regulating ion channels and receptors involved in neurological disorders and its potential therapeutic effects in CNS injury.
results_summary: Agmatine was found to regulate ion channel cascades and receptors linked to CNS disorders, with previous studies showing its involvement in cell differentiation, nitric oxide synthesis, pain relief, cerebral edema reduction, and prevention of apoptotic cell death.
population_specificity: Experimental models of CNS disorders (murine brain endothelial cells and chronic pain studies).

study_goal: The researchers examined how replacing chicken or pork with herring affects plasma metabolites, including agmatine levels.
results_summary: The herring diet decreased plasma agmatine levels, suggesting an impact on arginine metabolism, supported by increased nitric oxide in males.
population_specificity: 15 healthy obese men and women (age 24-70 years).

study_goal: The researchers were examining the role of LAT1 in transporting metabolites like agmatine and its potential as a drug target for cancer treatment.
results_summary: The abstract highlights LAT1's role in transporting essential amino acids and metabolites, including agmatine, across the Blood-Brain Barrier and its upregulation in cancer, suggesting its potential as a therapeutic target.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on cellular and cancer biology).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the specific mitochondrial functions of agmatine compared to other biologically active amines, particularly its role in mitochondrial permeability transition and apoptosis.
results_summary: The study suggests that agmatine, like spermine, has distinct mitochondrial functions, potentially influencing reactive oxygen species production and apoptosis, which could be leveraged for therapeutic strategies, such as in cancer treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (general mitochondrial studies in liver, kidney, heart, and brain cells).

study_goal: The researchers were reviewing the clinical phenotype of Retinitis Pigmentosa (RP) and retinal remodeling in RP, including studies on retinal degeneration in the rd/rd mouse model.
results_summary: The abstract does not mention Agmatine or its effects; it focuses on RP phenotype, retinal remodeling, and degeneration studies in the rd/rd mouse.
population_specificity: Retinitis Pigmentosa (human and rd/rd mouse model)

study_goal: The researchers were investigating the role of L-arginine metabolism in airway dysfunction in asthma and potential therapeutic interventions to modulate it.
results_summary: The abstract discusses the importance of nitric oxide (NO) in airway regulation and how impaired L-arginine metabolism contributes to reduced NO formation and airway dysfunction in asthma. It suggests that modulating L-arginine metabolism could help correct airway tone and responsiveness in asthma.
population_specificity: Asthma patients (implied, not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the effects of agmatine on CNS disorders and evaluate its potential as a pharmacological treatment for neurological and neurodegenerative diseases.
results_summary: Preclinical studies demonstrated agmatine's beneficial effects on depression, anxiety, hypoxic ischemia, nociception, morphine tolerance, memory, and various neurodegenerative disorders like Parkinson's and Alzheimer's disease. The study highlights agmatine's neuromodulatory and neuroprotective properties.
population_specificity: Preclinical studies (animal models and in vitro research).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of agmatine as a neurotransmitter and its neuroprotective effects in brain injury.
results_summary: The study identified agmatine as a neurotransmitter in mammals and highlighted its potential neuroprotective effects in brain injury, suggesting its involvement in CNS functions.
population_specificity: Mammals (not further specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the interactions and mechanisms of imidazoline receptors, including the role of endogenous ligands like agmatine, in physiological responses and toxicity.
results_summary: The study identified agmatine as one of the endogenous compounds binding to imidazoline receptors, but specific effects or outcomes related to agmatine were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing literature).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review preclinical and clinical evidence for agmatine's therapeutic potential in treating complex diseases with unmet needs, such as diabetes, neurotrauma, and mood disorders.
results_summary: The study highlights agmatine's broad modulatory effects on neurotransmitter systems, nitric oxide synthesis, and polyamine metabolism, supporting its potential for diverse therapeutic applications. Initial clinical evidence suggests promise, but challenges remain for widespread use.
population_specificity: Preclinical models and initial clinical studies (specific populations not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of agmatine in the central nervous system (CNS) and highlight its pharmacological actions in CNS disorders and drug development.
results_summary: The study found that agmatine exhibits analgesic, anxiolytic, and antidepressant activities in animals, improves cerebral damage and withdrawal syndromes, and modulates learning and memory processes. However, abnormal agmatine release may be linked to CNS disorders like schizophrenia.
population_specificity: Animal models (not specified further).
interactions: Interaction with glutamatergic and nitrergic systems mentioned.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review and update the information on the effects of agmatine in the central nervous system (CNS) and highlight its pharmacological importance in central disorders.
results_summary: Agmatine exhibited anticonvulsant, antinociceptive, anxiolytic, and antidepressant-like actions in experimental studies, with beneficial effects on cerebral ischemia models and modulation of withdrawal syndromes for addictive agents. However, aberrant release of agmatine in the CNS may be associated with mechanisms of disorders like psychosis.
population_specificity: Animal models and experimental studies (not specified for humans).
interactions: Interactions with glutamatergic and nitrergic systems mentioned, but no specific medications, foods, or supplements noted.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the clinical, biochemical, and molecular features of argininosuccinic aciduria (ASA), a urea cycle disorder, and discuss its treatment and diagnosis.
results_summary: The abstract does not directly address Agmatine's effects but mentions its synthesis from arginine, which is deficient in ASA due to ASL enzyme deficiency.
population_specificity: Patients with argininosuccinic aciduria (ASA), a urea cycle disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective effects of agmatine against rotenone-induced cellular injury in a human-derived dopaminergic neuroblastoma cell line (SH-SY5Y), focusing on mechanisms like oxidative stress reduction and mitochondrial preservation.
results_summary: Agmatine dose-dependently reduced rotenone-induced cellular injury by lowering oxidative stress, preventing nuclear factor-κB translocation, and mitigating mitochondrial dysfunction and apoptotic markers like caspase 3 activity, Bax expression, and cytochrome c release.
population_specificity: Human-derived dopaminergic neuroblastoma cell line (SH-SY5Y).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila could protect against ETEC infection and promote intestinal stem cell proliferation and differentiation via the Wnt/β-catenin signaling pathway.
results_summary: A. muciniphila reduced ETEC-induced intestinal inflammation, maintained Treg/Th17 cell balance, and stimulated intestinal epithelium proliferation and differentiation, with effects mediated by the Wnt/β-catenin pathway. Its protective effects were superior to B. fragilis and were reversed by a Wnt inhibitor.
population_specificity: Antibiotic-induced microbiome-disordered (AIMD) piglets, mice, and intestinal organoid models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and efficacy of dietary agmatine sulfate in treating herniated lumbar disc-associated radiculopathy.
results_summary: Agmatine sulfate was found to be safe, with only mild-to-moderate gastrointestinal side effects at the highest dose. It significantly improved pain measures and quality of life compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Participants diagnosed with herniated lumbar disc-associated radiculopathy.
effective_dosage: 1.335 g/day, 2.670 g/day, 3.560 g/day for 10-21 days in the dose escalation study; 2.670 g/day for 14 days in the follow-up study.
study_duration: 10-21 days in the dose escalation study; 14 days in the follow-up study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and characterize a phyto-postbiotic (C-Akm) derived from chicory extract fermented by Akkermansia muciniphila, assessing its potential anti-inflammatory and anti-obesity effects.
results_summary: The C-Akm extract reduced ROS generation, pro-inflammatory cytokine expression (TNF-α, IL-6, INFγ, IL-17A), and leptin secretion while increasing adiponectin and HSL expression in adipocytes and co-culture models, demonstrating anti-inflammatory and anti-obesity benefits.
population_specificity: In vitro models (THP-1 macrophages, LPS-stimulated PBMCs, human adipose stem cell-derived adipospheroids, and 3D co-culture mimicking inflamed obese adipose tissue).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how quercetin's modulation of Akkermansia muciniphila affects obesity-related phenotypes and bile acid metabolism.
results_summary: The study found that quercetin enriched Akkermansia muciniphila, leading to increased indole-3-lactic acid production, which upregulated CYP8B1 expression and facilitated cholesterol conversion to cholic acid, ultimately suppressing lipid accumulation via FXR activation.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely animal or in vitro model based on mechanistic focus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of Akkermansia muciniphila (AKK) on ulcerative colitis (UC) and its potential mechanism of action.
results_summary: AKK reduced colon tissue damage, alleviated oxidative stress and inflammation, upregulated Occludin-1 and SCFAs receptors, and promoted M1 to M2 macrophage polarization in mice. Silencing FFAR2 reversed these protective effects, suggesting AKK mediates its benefits via the SCFAs-SLC52A2/FFAR2 pathway.
population_specificity: DSS-induced UC mouse model and LPS-treated THP-1-M0 and raw264.7 macrophages.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Akkermansia muciniphila and its metabolite propionate on Alzheimer's disease (AD) pathology, focusing on mitochondrial homeostasis.
results_summary: The study found that AD patients had reduced Akkermansia muciniphila abundance and lower propionic acid levels. Administering A. muciniphila or propionate improved cognitive impairment, mitochondrial function, and mitophagy in AD mice.
population_specificity: Alzheimer's disease patients (human) and AD model mice (animal).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the combined therapeutic effects and immunomodulatory mechanisms of Akkermansia muciniphila (AKK) and Clostridium butyricum (CB) in treating inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and colitis-associated colorectal cancer (CRC).
results_summary: The study found that co-administration of AKK and CB significantly alleviated IBD symptoms, regulated gut microbiota, suppressed colonic inflammation, and inhibited CRC progression. Additionally, the combination enhanced sensitivity to immune checkpoint inhibitors and improved survival rates in CRC mice.
population_specificity: DSS/AOM-induced IBD and colitis-associated CRC mice models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether disulfiram (DSF) alleviates acetaminophen-induced acute liver injury (ALI) by modulating the gut microbiota, specifically the abundance of Akkermansia muciniphila.
results_summary: The study found that DSF restores intestinal microbiome balance by increasing Akkermansia muciniphila abundance, which in turn activates the PI3K/Akt pathway, corrects the Bcl-2/Bax ratio, and inhibits hepatocyte apoptosis, significantly alleviating ALI symptoms.
population_specificity: Not specified (animal or human study not explicitly stated in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a mucoadhesive probiotic Akkermansia muciniphila-mimic nanotherapeutic (AM@HMPB@E) for ulcerative colitis (UC) treatment by repairing the intestinal barrier and scavenging reactive oxygen/nitrogen species (RONS).
results_summary: The study found that AM@HMPB@E exhibited exceptional retention in colitis sites and superior therapeutic efficacy compared to sulfasalazine, evidenced by longer colon length, reduced rectal bleeding, and less body weight loss. The nanotherapeutic effectively eliminated RONS and repaired the intestinal epithelial barrier.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo models used).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of Akkermansia muciniphila in immune resistance in MAFLD-HCC patients and its potential as a predictive biomarker for PD1 response.
results_summary: Akkermansia muciniphila administration reduced liver steatosis and tumor growth in MAFLD-HCC mouse models, repaired the intestinal lining, decreased serum LPS and bile acid metabolites, and reduced m-MDSCs and M2 macrophages. Combining Akk with PD1 treatment enhanced T-cell infiltration and activation, improving tumor suppression.
population_specificity: MAFLD-HCC mouse models and clinical correlation in MAFLD-HCC patients.

study_goal: The researchers sought to investigate the therapeutic efficacy of different forms or strains of Akkermansia muciniphila in alleviating colitis and elucidate the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: Live Akkermansia muciniphila reduced colitis in a DSS-induced mouse model by promoting IL-22 secretion and enhancing RA synthesis in dendritic cells, while heat-inactivated Akk did not show the same effect. The novel strain Am06 demonstrated efficacy similar to the reference strain.
population_specificity: DSS-induced colitis mouse model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the beneficial role of Akkermansia muciniphila in managing intestinal inflammation, tumors, functional gastrointestinal disorders, and secondary conditions like liver and metabolic diseases.
results_summary: The study found that Akkermansia muciniphila plays a key role in intestinal homeostasis and has beneficial effects on various intestinal-related diseases, including inflammation, tumors, and metabolic disorders, with potential for clinical applications.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of experimental and clinical studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of Akkermansia muciniphila (Akk) and pasteurized Akk (PA-Akk) on lipid absorption in the proximal intestine and its metabolic benefits.
results_summary: Long-term administration of Akk reduced lipid deposits in the liver and adipocytes, improved glucose metabolism, and inhibited lipid absorption in the jejunum by activating AMPK. Akk also promoted the abundance of core jejunal microbes, while PA-Akk did not show the same effects.
population_specificity: Mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pasteurized Akkermansia muciniphila (pAKK) could serve as a safer and effective alternative to live AKK for treating preeclampsia by improving endothelial function and metabolic regulation.
results_summary: pAKK showed therapeutic effects comparable to live AKK in improving preeclampsia-like symptoms, including enhanced gut barrier function, reduced endotoxemia, and restored placental angiogenesis via eNOS activity and NO production. Metabolomic analysis indicated pAKK reversed metabolic disturbances related to unsaturated fatty acid biosynthesis, folate, and linoleic acid metabolism.
population_specificity: Preeclampsia mouse model and human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the correlation between Akkermansia muciniphila abundance and benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) severity and metabolic indices, as well as evaluate the effects of AKK administration in a BPH mouse model.
results_summary: The study found reduced Akkermansia abundance in BPH patients, negatively correlated with symptom severity and metabolic markers. AKK administration in mice improved histopathology, reduced prostate index, and showed trends toward metabolic improvement, along with reduced inflammation and restored gut barrier integrity.
population_specificity: BPH patients and healthy donors (human study), testosterone-induced BPH mouse model (animal study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Akkermansia muciniphila's outer membrane protein Amuc_1100 on NK cells in lung adenocarcinoma (LUAD) and elucidate its potential molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that elevated AKK levels in LUAD patients correlated with increased NK cell infiltration and reduced TGF-β levels. Amuc_1100 treatment enhanced NK cell cytotoxicity, upregulated perforin and granzyme B, and inhibited cancer cell proliferation by suppressing the TGF-β pathway.
population_specificity: Lung adenocarcinoma (LUAD) patients and a xenograft mouse model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila modifies the association between prenatal metal exposures and depressive symptoms in childhood.
results_summary: A subgroup of children with prenatal exposure to zinc-chromium-cobalt had higher depression scores, but those with Akkermansia muciniphila in their gut microbiome showed significantly lower depression scores compared to those without it. The study suggests A. muciniphila may attenuate the depressive effects of prenatal metal exposure.
population_specificity: Children aged 9-11 years from a pediatric birth cohort (n = 112).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of pasteurized Akkermansia muciniphila on gut microbiota composition, inflammation, and metabolic complications in an obese-diabetic zebrafish model.
results_summary: Pasteurized A. muciniphila was found to be safe and potentially more cost-effective than live strains, with implications for obesity and diabetes management. The study suggests further investigation into its effects on metabolic pathways and inflammation.
population_specificity: Obese-diabetic zebrafish (Danio rerio) model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Akkermansia muciniphila (AKK ONE) on DSS-induced colitis in mice, focusing on its potential as a therapeutic agent for ulcerative colitis.
results_summary: AKK ONE supplementation improved food intake, weight, colon length, disease activity index, and intestinal barrier integrity while reducing inflammation and altering gut microbiota composition. It also increased short-chain fatty acids in cecal contents.
population_specificity: DSS-induced colitis mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and genotoxicity of a powder formulation of viable Akkermansia muciniphila (AMUC) as a potential food ingredient.
results_summary: The study found no mortality, adverse effects, or bacterial translocation at doses up to 2000 mg/kg/day (1.64 × 10^11 CFU/kg/day). AMUC showed no mutagenic, clastogenic, or genotoxic effects in in vitro and in vivo assays.
population_specificity: Rats
effective_dosage: 0, 500, 1000, and 2000 mg/kg body weight/day (equivalent to 0, 4.1 × 10^10, 9.2 × 10^10, and 1.64 × 10^11 CFU/kg/day)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether heat-killed Akkermansia muciniphila could improve gut microbiota diversity, metabolic signaling, and blood glucose levels in a mouse model of type 1 diabetes.
results_summary: Heat-killed Akkermansia muciniphila increased gut microbiota diversity, elevated immune and metabolic signaling pathways, and promoted insulin-like growth factor 2 (IGF2) secretion, leading to improved muscle and global metabolism in diabetic mice.
population_specificity: Mice with streptozotocin (STZ)-induced type 1 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila increases intestinal secretory IgA (SIgA) production in early-weaned piglets and mice.
results_summary: The study found that Akkermansia muciniphila significantly increased SIgA levels, SIgA-coated bacteria abundance, and IgA+ plasma cell counts in mice, and similarly enhanced intestinal SIgA concentrations in piglets while altering the SIgA-coated bacterial landscape.
population_specificity: Early-weaned piglets (Huanjiang miniature and Duroc×Landrace×Yorkshire breeds) and specific pathogen-free C57BL/6J mice.
effective_dosage: 10^9 and 10^8 CFU of A. muciniphila (piglet study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila could prevent cognitive impairments and anxiety-related behavior in tau protein-induced Alzheimer's Disease (AD) rats by modulating the gut-brain axis.
results_summary: A. muciniphila significantly reduced anxiety-like behavior, improved spatial and recognition memory, and decreased pro-inflammatory cytokine levels (TNF-α, IL-1β, IL-6, IFN-γ) in AD rats compared to untreated controls.
population_specificity: Tau protein-induced Alzheimer's Disease (AD) rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of Akkermansia muciniphila in improving liver fibrosis and hyperammonemia in a murine model of liver cirrhosis.
results_summary: The study found that administration of Akkermansia muciniphila improved liver fibrosis and hyperammonemia, with changes in bacterial composition in the small intestine, suggesting its potential as a microbial intervention for liver cirrhosis.
population_specificity: Murine (mouse) model of liver cirrhosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role and underlying mechanism of Akkermansia muciniphila (AKK) in obesity-associated atherosclerosis and its potential therapeutic effects.
results_summary: AKK supplementation improved dyslipidemia, reduced atherosclerotic lesion formation, enhanced cardiac function, decreased body weight, modulated inflammatory cytokines (reduced IL-6, increased IL-10), and regulated gut microbiota by increasing Lactobacillaceae abundance.
population_specificity: ApoE-/- mice (a model for atherosclerosis) and human fecal samples from healthy controls and atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ACVD) patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a gastrointestinal self-adaptive and nutrient self-sufficient Akkermansia muciniphila (AKK) delivery system (AKK@GPMGs) for enhanced synergistic therapy of ulcerative colitis (UC).
results_summary: AKK@GPMGs significantly improved resistance to stomach acid, enhanced intestinal colonization, restored mucus layer integrity, reduced inflammation and oxidative stress, and regulated gut microbiota homeostasis, demonstrating superior therapeutic effects compared to uncoated AKK.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely preclinical or animal model based on abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila extracellular vesicles (AmEVs) protect against hypertension by modulating gene expression in the kidneys of spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHRs).
results_summary: AmEVs protected against hypertension in SHRs without serious adverse reactions and modulated the expression of vasocontracting and vasodilating genes in the kidneys of both SHRs and Wistar-Kyoto rats (WKYs). The results suggest AmEVs may serve as a novel therapeutic for hypertension.
population_specificity: Spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHRs) and Wistar-Kyoto rats (WKYs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the beneficial effects of Akkermansia muciniphila on various diseases and summarize its potential mechanisms of action.
results_summary: The study found that Akkermansia muciniphila is associated with improved metabolic and immune functions, and its beneficial effects extend to live, pasteurized forms, extracellular vesicles, outer membrane, and secreted proteins. The review highlights a shift from correlation studies to mechanistic insights in animal and preclinical models.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of multiple studies, including animal and preclinical models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of Akkermansia muciniphila in delaying castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC) and its potential therapeutic effects via the LPS/NF-κB/AR axis.
results_summary: The study found that Akkermansia muciniphila enrichment was associated with delayed CRPC progression, linked to increased serum inosine levels. Supplementing inosine improved intestinal barrier function, reduced LPS levels, and inhibited CRPC via the LPS/NF-κB/AR pathway.
population_specificity: Prostate cancer patients and mice models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the influence of Akkermansia muciniphila and its derivatives on gastrointestinal and metabolic disorders through a meta-analysis of mouse model studies.
results_summary: A. muciniphila and its derivatives improved systemic and gut inflammation, liver enzyme levels, glycemic response, lipid profiles, and gut permeability. Live bacteria had a more substantial effect on most biomarkers, and a co-occurring microbial cluster was identified.
population_specificity: Mouse models of gastrointestinal and metabolic disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Akkermansia muciniphila and photobiomodulation (PBM) on promoting anti-inflammatory M2 macrophage polarization in gliadin-stimulated and non-stimulated THP-1 derived macrophages.
results_summary: The study found that PBM combined with A. muciniphila increased anti-inflammatory cytokines (TGF-β, IL-10) and modulated inflammatory responses in gliadin-stimulated macrophages, suggesting potential therapeutic benefits for inflammatory conditions like celiac disease.
population_specificity: Human monocyte cell line (THP-1) derived macrophages, both gliadin-stimulated and non-stimulated.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine changes in Akkermansia muciniphila abundance in response to exercise across various study designs in humans and rodents.
results_summary: Human studies showed mixed results, with some reporting increases, others decreases, and no significant differences in A. muciniphila abundance, while rodent studies consistently demonstrated increased abundance following aerobic exercise.
population_specificity: Humans (522 participants, including 157 athletes) and rodents (310 animals, mostly mice).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify herbal drug extracts that promote the growth of Akkermansia muciniphila and assess their potential to improve metabolic health in obese mice.
results_summary: Five herbal extracts increased A. muciniphila levels, with Dioscoreae rhizoma extract notably enhancing growth in high-fat-diet mice, reducing weight gain, and improving glucose tolerance. The findings suggest A. muciniphila-boosting herbal extracts could be a therapeutic strategy for metabolic syndrome.
population_specificity: Mice fed a high-fat diet

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role and mechanisms of Akkermansia muciniphila (AKK) in mitigating the effects of ischemic stroke, particularly its impact on neuroinflammation and neuronal damage.
results_summary: AKK administration significantly improved body weight, reduced infarct volumes, decreased degenerating neurons and apoptotic cells, and lowered neuroinflammation by reducing astrocyte and microglia activation while upregulating anti-inflammatory factors.
population_specificity: Mice subjected to ischemic stroke via a rose bengal photothrombosis model.
study_duration: Administered prior to stroke surgery, with outcomes assessed at 3 days post-stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the role of Akkermansia muciniphila in gut health and its potential as a therapeutic target for intestinal diseases.
results_summary: The study found that Akkermansia muciniphila has beneficial effects in various diseases, including diabetes, obesity, aging, cancer, and metabolic syndrome, and may enhance intestinal barrier integrity. It is recognized as a promising probiotic for gut health.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of potential applications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the factors and molecular mechanisms by which Akkermansia muciniphila (AKK) and its outer membrane protein Amuc_1100 influence immune escape in lung adenocarcinoma (LUAD).
results_summary: AKK and Amuc_1100 enhanced CD8+ T cell recruitment and toxicity, suppressed PD-L1, p-STAT, and p-JAK expression, and increased CCL5, granzyme B, and INF-γ levels, demonstrating antitumour effects in vitro and in vivo.
population_specificity: Lung adenocarcinoma (LUAD) cell lines (A549, NCI-H1395) and a subcutaneous graft tumour mouse model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of Akkermansia muciniphila and its metabolite PEA in enhancing oxaliplatin efficacy in gastric cancer treatment.
results_summary: The study found that Akkermansia muciniphila promotes oxaliplatin efficacy by producing pentadecanoic acid (PEA), which inhibits glycolysis in cancer cells via FUBP1 antagonism, thereby improving chemotherapy response.
population_specificity: Gastric cancer mouse model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to sequence and analyze the genome of Akkermansia muciniphila ONE (AKK ONE) and evaluate its safety through toxicological studies.
results_summary: The study found that AKK ONE has a well-characterized genome with no detected virulence-related genes and is non-pathogenic. It demonstrated good safety in toxicological tests, with no adverse effects observed in mice at a dose of 8.28 × 10^9 CFU/kg bw/day.
population_specificity: Mice (animal study)
study_duration: Acute and subchronic toxicity tests (specific duration not mentioned)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how Akkermansia muciniphila (AKK) contributes to the therapeutic effects of LGYD in treating radiation-induced intestinal injury (RIII) by modulating gut microbiota and short-chain fatty acid (SCFA) production.
results_summary: The study found that LGYD increased AKK abundance and SCFA levels, particularly isobutyric acid, which promoted recovery from RIII. AKK and LGYD-DS enhanced intestinal stem cell restoration and improved survival rates post-radiation.
population_specificity: Radiation-induced intestinal injury model (in vivo and organoid models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila (AKK) plays a role in the antidepressant effects of Hypericum perforatum L. (HPL) by modulating gut microbiota and tryptophan metabolism.
results_summary: The study found that HPL enriched AKK, which increased serotonin (5-HT) levels and reduced kynurenine (KYN), alleviating depression symptoms by modulating the NFκB-NLRP2-Caspase1-IL1β pathway. Mono-colonization with AKK replicated these effects, confirming its role in HPL's antidepressant mechanism.
population_specificity: CRS-induced depression model mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the roles of Akkermansia muciniphila in various health domains, including metabolic, inflammatory, and neurodegenerative diseases, and its potential therapeutic applications.
results_summary: The study found that Akkermansia muciniphila plays a key role in gut integrity, immune modulation, and metabolic processes, with potential benefits for obesity, diabetes, inflammatory bowel disease, and neuropsychiatric conditions. Challenges in practical application due to stability and cultivation issues were noted, but pasteurized forms and synthetic mediums offer new clinical avenues.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of animal and preliminary human studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Akkermansia muciniphila in alleviating diabetic cognitive impairment (DCI) in db/db mice and understand its specific effects and mechanisms.
results_summary: Live A. muciniphila significantly improved cognitive impairments, synaptic ultrastructure, and reduced hippocampal neuron loss, while both live and pasteurized forms mitigated neuroinflammation. The effects were linked to changes in gut microbiota and serum/brain metabolites, particularly in tryptophan metabolism and other pathways.
population_specificity: Eleven-week-old db/db mice (a model for diabetes and cognitive impairment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Akkermansia muciniphila on pancreatic β-cell function, apoptosis, differentiation, and related mechanisms in a prediabetic rat model, comparing it with dietary intervention.
results_summary: Both A. muciniphila and dietary intervention reduced metaflammation, repaired the intestinal barrier, and improved β-cell function, apoptosis, and differentiation via TLR2 and TLR4 signaling pathways. A. muciniphila further enhanced these effects beyond dietary intervention alone.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-induced prediabetic rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether engineered Lactococcus lactis producing P9 protein from Akkermansia muciniphila could stimulate GLP-1 release and improve glucose homeostasis.
results_summary: The study found that recombinant L. lactis NZP9 successfully secreted P9 protein, which stimulated GLP-1 production in NCI-H716 cells and upregulated GLP-1 biosynthesis genes. The results suggest potential therapeutic applications for metabolic disorders like diabetes and obesity.
population_specificity: HFD-induced mice and NCI-H716 cells (a human intestinal endocrine cell line).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Akkermansia muciniphila and its outer membrane proteins on gastric cancer, focusing on apoptosis, immune modulation, and tumor growth inhibition.
results_summary: AKK and its outer membrane proteins promoted apoptosis in gastric cancer cells, stimulated immune responses (M1 macrophage polarization, cytotoxic T-lymphocyte activation, Treg suppression), and inhibited tumor growth while enhancing immune cell infiltration in tumor tissues.
population_specificity: Gastric cancer models (in vitro and in vivo)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila could improve gut health and protect against ETEC infection in weaned piglets.
results_summary: Akkermansia muciniphila supplementation reduced diarrhea rates, improved intestinal morphology, enhanced immune response, and lowered ETEC virulence gene expression, with the live low-dose group showing the most significant benefits. However, the heat-killed low-dose group had a higher diarrhea rate than controls.
population_specificity: Weaned piglets (28 days old)
effective_dosage: Live A. muciniphila (1 × 10^10 CFU/5 mL or 5 × 10^8 CFU/5 mL) or heat-killed A. muciniphila (same doses), administered every other day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the probiotic Lactiplantibacillus fermentum F6 could modulate Akkermansia muciniphila levels and ameliorate colitis in a rat model.
results_summary: The study found that administering the probiotic reduced Akkermansia muciniphila levels in colitis rats, correlating with improved disease markers such as lower inflammation and histopathology scores. The results suggest that the probiotic's mechanism may involve targeted reduction of specific gut microbes linked to disease.
population_specificity: Dextran sulfate sodium-induced colitis rat model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of combining Akkermansia muciniphila with inosine for alleviating alcohol-induced liver injury by improving gut-liver axis function and immune modulation.
results_summary: The combination of A. muciniphila and inosine significantly reduced liver injury markers, improved intestinal barrier function, restored beneficial gut microbiota, and modulated immune responses, particularly Treg/Th17/Th1 cell balance, with effects partly dependent on A2AR activation.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6 mice with alcohol-induced liver injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between gastrointestinal reactive oxygen species (ROS), dietary antioxidants, and the beneficial gut bacterium Akkermansia muciniphila, particularly its role in obesity and metabolic dysfunction.
results_summary: The study found that A. muciniphila was more abundant in lean mice and negatively correlated with GI ROS levels. Grape polyphenols, but not other antioxidants, stimulated A. muciniphila growth, likely due to their poor bioavailability enhancing radical scavenging in the GI tract.
population_specificity: Lean (n = 20) and obese (n = 7) mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila (Akk) supplementation could improve Parkinson's disease (PD) symptoms and neuroprotection in a mouse model.
results_summary: Akk treatment reduced dopaminergic neuron loss, improved motor function, alleviated neuroinflammation, promoted hippocampal neurogenesis, and decreased colon inflammation, likely linked to changes in serum and fecal isovaleric acid levels and lower intestinal permeability.
population_specificity: MPTP-induced subacute PD model mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe and discuss the mechanisms of Akkermansia muciniphila as an intestinal microbiota or probiotic in colorectal cancer (CRC).
results_summary: The role of A. muciniphila in CRC development or inhibition remains unclear and controversial, with some studies suggesting increased abundance in CRC patients while others associate decreased abundance with severe symptoms. Preliminary human data indicate oral consumption is safe, but efficacy requires further confirmation.
population_specificity: CRC patients and healthy individuals (comparative analysis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Akkermansia muciniphila as a probiotic to mitigate olanzapine-induced weight gain and metabolic side effects.
results_summary: Akkermansia muciniphila improved weight gain, insulin resistance, hyperglycemia, liver function, systemic inflammation, and gut barrier function in both mice models and clinical populations, demonstrating efficacy in reducing antipsychotic-induced metabolic impairment.
population_specificity: Psychiatric patients suffering from antipsychotic side effects and mice models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of diosmin (DIO) on Akkermansia muciniphila abundance and its role in improving intestinal barrier function and reducing inflammation in DSS-induced colitis.
results_summary: DIO administration increased A. muciniphila abundance and MUC2 expression while reducing oxidative stress and inflammation, improving intestinal barrier integrity via regulation of NF-κB, Nrf2, PIK3R3, and ZO-1 pathways.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice with DSS-induced colitis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila extracellular vesicles (AmEVs) have a protective effect against hypertension and their potential mechanism of action.
results_summary: AmEVs protected against hypertension development in spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHRs) without serious adverse reactions, increased T regulatory (Treg) cell populations, and tended to reduce proinflammatory cytokines. No effect was observed on vascular contraction or endothelial relaxation in thoracic aortas.
population_specificity: Wistar-Kyoto rats (WKYs) and spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHRs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila modifies the association between prenatal metal exposures and childhood depressive symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that in children without A. muciniphila, a metal-clique (Zinc-Chromium-Cobalt) was strongly associated with increased depression scores, whereas in children with A. muciniphila, the same metal-clique was weakly associated with decreased depression scores. This suggests A. muciniphila may attenuate the depressive effects of prenatal metal exposure.
population_specificity: 9-11-year-old children from a pediatric longitudinal birth cohort (n=112).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the curative effects of Akkermansia muciniphila on colitis-induced inflammation and enteric nervous system degeneration.
results_summary: The study demonstrated that A. muciniphila ameliorated inflammation and ENS damage in a TNBS-induced chronic colitis model, suggesting potential benefits for IBD treatment.
population_specificity: TNBS-induced chronic colitis model (animal study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the roles and mechanisms of Akkermansia muciniphila in infectious diseases and its potential as a therapeutic probiotic.
results_summary: The study found that Akkermansia muciniphila has beneficial effects, including protecting intestinal barrier integrity, modulating immune responses, and potential applications in treating infectious diseases like sepsis, viral infections, and periodontitis. However, its specific roles and mechanisms in infectious diseases remain unclear.
population_specificity: Human gut microbiome (general population, not specified further).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the potential of pasteurized Akkermansia muciniphila for alleviating IBS-like symptoms in mouse models and explore its neuromodulatory effects.
results_summary: Pasteurized Akkermansia muciniphila significantly reduced colonic hypersensitivity, reinforced intestinal barrier function, improved anxiety-like behavior and memory defects, and exhibited neuroinhibitory effects on neuronal cells.
population_specificity: C57BL6/J mice with IBS-like symptoms induced by neonatal maternal separation or Citrobacter rodentium infection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the contradictory roles of Akkermansia muciniphila in colorectal cancer, exploring its protective and pathogenic effects in different experimental models.
results_summary: The study found that A. muciniphila has both protective and pathogenic effects in colorectal cancer models, with outcomes varying based on administration protocols, bacterial viability, and interactions with other gut bacteria. Immunomodulatory effects of surface antigens were also noted.
population_specificity: Mice (animal models)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila could alleviate radiation-induced intestinal damage and inflammation.
results_summary: The study found that A. muciniphila abundance decreased after abdominal irradiation, and its administration mitigated intestinal damage and prevented death in mice. Propionic acid, a metabolite of A. muciniphila, was identified as the key mediator of these protective effects by enhancing intestinal barrier integrity.
population_specificity: Mice exposed to abdominal irradiation and human patients receiving abdominal radiotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila enhances the efficacy of PD-1 monoclonal antibody therapy in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) and explore its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that Akkermansia muciniphila improved PD-1mAb efficacy in HCC by promoting tumor cell apoptosis, increasing CD8+ T cell proportion, downregulating PD-L1 expression, and altering bile acid metabolism, leading to higher serum TUDCA levels.
population_specificity: Tumor-bearing mouse model (HCC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila-derived extracellular vesicles (Akk EVs) could modulate the intestinal barrier, reduce inflammation, and prevent colitis.
results_summary: Akk EVs reduced inflammatory markers (NO, TNF-α, IL-1β) in LPS-induced cells, improved intestinal barrier function (increased MUC2 expression, reduced permeability), and modulated gut microbiota (increased Firmicutes, decreased Proteobacteria) in a DSS-induced colitis mouse model.
population_specificity: LPS-induced RAW264.7 cells and DSS-induced colitis mouse model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila could improve LPS-induced acute lung injury by modulating gut microbiota and reducing inflammation.
results_summary: A. muciniphila attenuated lung tissue damage, reduced oxidative stress and inflammation, maintained intestinal barrier function, reshaped gut microbiota, and promoted SCFA secretion, particularly butyrate, which downregulated the TLR2/MyD88/NF-κB pathway.
population_specificity: Mice with LPS-induced acute lung injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila mediates the protective effects of astaxanthin (AST) in chronic prostatitis/chronic pelvic pain syndrome (CP/CPPS) and its role in alleviating inflammation and pain.
results_summary: The study found that Akkermansia muciniphila levels were decreased in CP/CPPS patients and EAP mice, and oral administration of AST increased its abundance, which correlated with reduced inflammation and pain. Supplementation with A. muciniphila alone also alleviated symptoms in EAP mice.
population_specificity: Experimental autoimmune prostatitis (EAP) mice and CP/CPPS patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of Akkermansia muciniphila (AKK) and its extracellular vesicles (AmEvs) in improving postoperative cognitive dysfunction (POCD) by examining gut and blood-brain barrier integrity, inflammation, and microglial function.
results_summary: Supplementation with AKK or AmEvs improved cognitive function, enhanced intestinal and blood-brain barrier integrity, reduced inflammation, and inhibited microglial activation in POCD mice. AmEvs also suppressed TLR2/4 signaling in the brain and microglial cells, though their protective effects were lost in microglial-ablated mice.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 J mice with induced POCD via intestinal ischemia-reperfusion (I/R).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether lycium barbarum polysaccharide, yam polysaccharide, and chrysanthemum polysaccharide (LYC) could improve drug-induced liver injury (DILI) by increasing the abundance of Akkermansia muciniphila.
results_summary: The study found that LYC increased A. muciniphila abundance, reduced intestinal inflammation and permeability, and improved intestinal barrier function by upregulating tight junction proteins (ZO-1 and occludin). Additionally, LYC inhibited LPS leakage and upregulated hepatic YAP1 expression, leading to DILI repair.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice (APAP-induced DILI model) and KM mice (antibiotic-treated).
effective_dosage: Optimal concentration ratio of WYC was 2:3:2, and LYC was 1:1:1 (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of oral administration of Akkermansia muciniphila on alcoholic liver disease (ALD) by examining its effects on gut microbiota and host metabolism.
results_summary: The study found that Akkermansia muciniphila alleviated alcohol-induced liver injury, improved serum levels of ornithine, reduced oxalic acid levels, inhibited harmful bacteria proliferation, and promoted beneficial bacteria growth.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice with induced ALD using a modified NIAAA model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila could ameliorate helminth-induced cardiac fibrosis (CF) in mice and explore its mechanism of action.
results_summary: The study found that Akkermansia muciniphila was more abundant in Ts-infected mice and that oral supplementation with live or pasteurized A. muciniphila improved CF via TLR2 signaling.
population_specificity: Ts-infected mice (animal model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Akkermansia muciniphila and its outer membrane protein Amuc_1100 on nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) in mice, comparing its efficacy to atorvastatin.
results_summary: A. muciniphila and Amuc_1100 significantly reduced body weight, improved serum lipid levels, lowered liver enzyme levels (ALT and AST), decreased inflammation markers (NLRP3, TLR4/NF-κB), and modulated gut microbiota composition in NAFLD mice, with effects comparable to atorvastatin.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-induced NAFLD mouse model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the role of Akkermansia muciniphila in colorectal cancer (CRC) development and its molecular mechanism, focusing on tryptophan-mediated AhR/β-catenin signaling.
results_summary: The study found that Akkermansia muciniphila inhibited CRC formation by down-regulating tryptophan-mediated AhR signaling, and its antitumor effects were abolished in AhR-deficient models, suggesting a protective role via specific inhibition of AhR/β-catenin signaling.
population_specificity: Mice models (AOM/DSS and ApcMin/+) and human colon cancer tumor models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how Akkermansia muciniphila contributes to improved glucose metabolism and reduced obesity, particularly in the context of isoxanthohumol (IX) administration.
results_summary: The study found that IX administration increased Akkermansia muciniphila abundance, which was linked to improved glucose metabolism, reduced CD36 expression in the jejunum, and decreased plasma fatty acid levels. Monocolonization of A. muciniphila in germ-free mice replicated these metabolic benefits.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-fed mice, including antibiotic-treated and germ-free mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the role of Akkermansia muciniphila in tumorigenesis and tumor therapy, focusing on its potential as a next-generation probiotic.
results_summary: The study found that Akkermansia muciniphila's components and metabolites can influence tumorigenesis, particularly through antitumor immunosurveillance, and may improve outcomes in cancer prevention and treatment. It highlights the bacterium's potential as a therapeutic agent but notes unresolved scientific issues for clinical application.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of gut microbiota in diseases like diabetes, obesity, aging, and cancers).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila, in combination with glutamine, could mitigate renal interstitial fibrosis (RIF) in a mouse model of unilateral ureteral obstruction (UUO).
results_summary: The study found that Akkermansia muciniphila colonization, along with glutamine supplementation, effectively reduced cell apoptosis and renal fibrosis in UUO mice, suggesting a gut-renal axis mechanism. SPX treatment increased A. muciniphila levels and modulated glutamine-related metabolism, contributing to renal protection.
population_specificity: Mice with unilateral ureteral obstruction (UUO) as a model for renal interstitial fibrosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if pasteurized Akkermansia muciniphila controls glycemia via a gut-brain axis and impacts gut motility in a high-fat diet mouse model.
results_summary: Pasteurized A. muciniphila improved metabolic parameters (body weight, fat mass, insulin, glycemia, glucose tolerance) by reducing duodenal contraction and increasing hypothalamic nitric oxide release in high-fat diet mice.
population_specificity: Mice fed a 45% high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the proposed roles and mechanisms of Akkermansia muciniphila in neuropsychiatric disorders and explore its potential therapeutic applications.
results_summary: The study found that Akkermansia muciniphila improves symptoms of neuropsychiatric disorders by restoring gut microbiota, enhancing gut barrier integrity, and modulating immunity and inflammation, though it may also exacerbate inflammation in some cases. The exact mechanism remains controversial.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of clinical and preclinical studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of Akkermansia muciniphila on the human immune system and its potential to enhance cancer immunotherapy by improving efficacy and reducing side effects.
results_summary: The study found that Akkermansia muciniphila significantly inhibits carcinogenesis, improves anti-tumor effects, and enhances the effectiveness of cancer immunotherapy while reducing the likelihood of side effects. The review highlights its potential clinical applications in anti-tumor therapy.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of existing research)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Akkermansia muciniphila could inhibit Fusobacterium nucleatum's effects and alleviate periodontitis.
results_summary: Akkermansia muciniphila inhibited F. nucleatum's virulence gene expression and reduced inflammatory effects on gingival epithelial cells by modulating the TLR/MyD88/NF-κB pathway. Animal experiments confirmed A. muciniphila's ability to inhibit F. nucleatum-induced periodontitis in mice.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice and in vitro gingival epithelial cells (GECs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current knowledge on correlations between Akkermansia muciniphila and neuropsychological diseases, focusing on its potential as a therapeutic target.
results_summary: The study highlights A. muciniphila's role in neuropsychological diseases, emphasizing its outer membrane proteins as potential therapeutic targets, supported by evidence from animal and clinical studies.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether Akkermansia muciniphila could prevent NAFLD, its mechanisms of action, and its effects on gut microbiota modulation.
results_summary: Akkermansia muciniphila attenuated weight gain, insulin resistance, liver lipid deposition, and pro-inflammatory factors while improving gut barrier function and modulating beneficial microbiota. It also activated hepatic FXR and suppressed intestinal FXR.
population_specificity: Mice fed a high-fat diet for 20 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of Akkermansia muciniphila and other microbiome-targeted interventions to enhance immune responses and improve outcomes in renal cell carcinoma patients treated with immune checkpoint inhibitors.
results_summary: The study found that Akkermansia muciniphila, along with other strains, enhances immune responses and progression-free survival in metastatic renal cell carcinoma patients. However, prospective randomized trials are needed to standardize clinical applications.
population_specificity: Patients with metastatic renal cell carcinoma (RCC) undergoing immune checkpoint inhibitor therapy.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the potential impact of intestinal dysbiosis, including Akkermansia muciniphila, on lung diseases through the gut-lung connection.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings regarding Akkermansia muciniphila's effects.
population_specificity: General population with respiratory symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pasteurized Akkermansia muciniphila (HB05P) could improve muscle function in older adults with sarcopenia.
results_summary: The HB05P group showed significant improvements in peak torque and peak torque per body weight of the left leg extensor muscles compared to the placebo group.
population_specificity: Individuals aged 60 and above.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of Akkermansia muciniphila in gut microbiota alterations and its potential impact on childhood obesity.
